text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- The interests of the Russian government and different energy and financial groups have come into conflict over the shares of Tyumen Oil Company.
- Two big Russian commercial banks have joined a special state fund which finances the country's agricultural producers.
- Some Russian politicians suggest that Russia should join the World Trade Organisation only if it is together with Belarus.
- A peace agreement signed in Moscow on Friday by Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov and Islamic leader Sayid Abdullo Nuri is an achievement of Russia's foreign policy.
- Privatisation of Russia's biggest state-owned insurance company, Rosgosstrakh, has turned into a scandal which is likely to be cleared up only in court.
- Bulgarian tobacco is losing its position on the Russian market.
SEVODNYA

- Politicalistion of the armed forces is more dangerous for the military's stability than wage arrears, says the paper in a comment on an address by General Lev Rokhlin criticisng President Boris Yeltsin's military reform plans.
- Alfred Kokh, the head of the State Property Commity, wants to go ahead with the privatisation of Rosgosstrakh insurance company.
- Russia's oil and gas producers have criticised the new Tax Code for not responding to the interests of the fuel and energy sector.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- Russia could have used the Hong Kong experience in resolving its own territorial problems.
- Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin was amazed by China's economic achievements.
ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA

- The State Duma lower house of parliament has failed to pass a number of very important laws which could have change an 'absurd' social situation in the country, says Sergei Belyayev, leader of the Our Home is Russia parliamentary group.
SOVIETSKAYA ROSSIA
- All recent legal initiatives by the government are meant to create a judicial framework for an absurd economic system.
KOMSOMOLSKAYA PRAVDA
- Russia wants to save the Mir orbiting station because without it the country would lose its independent space programme.
-- Svetlana Kovaleva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
